awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modulating Single-Atom Catalytic Centers in Well-Defined Metal Oxide Nanocrystal Surfaces for Oxygen Evolution Reaction
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of renewable alternatives to fossil fuel-based energy is one of the most critical scientific challenges of the United States. Electrocatalysis is a cornerstone to bridging renewable electrical energy resources (solar, hydro, and wind power, etc.) with chemical transformations central to energy storage and conversion. The project will develop an emerging class of electrocatalytic materials to maximize the efficiency of hydrogen fuel production from water. The outcome of this project makes a major contribution to hydrogen fuel technology development and supports the nation’s efforts to diversify energy supply and reduce the dependence on non-renewable energy sources. The knowledge generated from this project will advance general understanding and research in catalysis and other technologies, including batteries and sensors. The research is supplemented by a range of educational and outreach activities primarily for K-12 and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to increase their interest in careers as scientists and engineers.

This project represents a cross-disciplinary and cross-institute effort to develop well-defined single atom catalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) - the key barrier reaction for water electrolyzer and renewable hydrogen production. The project integrates the co-investigators' respective expertise in experimental and computational catalysis to address three questions paramount to OER catalysis: how to identify or construct well-defined catalytic centers for OER; how to delineate unambiguously the atomistic mechanism for OER at this center; and how to leverage the mechanistic understanding and the synthetic technique to fine-tune catalytic centers for optimal kinetics.  The primary strategy is to computationally design and precisely synthesize single-atom catalytic centers (e.g. cobalt) in the surface of well-defined and chemically stable metal oxide nanocrystals, thereby optimizing the OER performance through mechanistic understanding and synthetic modulation. Three specific tasks are included: (1) synthesizing cobalt single-atom catalytic centers with diverse and controllable metal oxide phase, composition, and surface facets; (2) understanding dependence of the reaction mechanism and kinetics on composition and atomic structure through a combination of computational and experimental approaches; and (3) using this understanding to conduct in silico scanning of reasonable compositions, combined with Machine Learning based on the validated computational model, followed by experimental synthesis of the predicted best candidates to identify the optimal single-atom and metal oxide compositions. Educational outreach involves the participation of undergraduate and K-12 students in summer research internships in the investigators’ laboratories as well as visits by the investigators and graduate students to the minority-serving partner institutions to deliver short courses based on their research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
One major goal was to develop new computational methods to predict accurately the rates and products of electrocatalytic reactions as a function of applied potential and to validate the accuracy by comparing to experiments by Prof. Sen Zhang of U. Virginia on Single Crystal nanocatalysts and on nanomaterials and to other experiments with a focus on

  • The oxygen evolution reaction (OER),
  • The Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER),
  • The N2 reduction reaction (N2RR) to NH3, and
  • The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) critical for hydrogen fuel cells

The second major goal was to apply these now validated new methods to in silico prediction of new electrocatalysts, ranking them, and selecting only the best to be tested experimentally.

Highlights of accomplishments 

1. Grand Canonical Potential Kinetics (GCP-K), We developed and validated a new computation technology, the Grand Canonical Potential Kinetics (GCP-K), or GC-QM, that leads to accurate free energy reaction barriers and energetics for all the steps of OER, HER, N2RR, and ORR under the conditions of electrocatalyst experiments.

Here exactly the same potential is applied to all reaction steps (9 for OER), including the reaction transition states. Normal QM has a fixed number of electrons, so that the potential changes between initial state, transition state, and final state; hence it cannot be used for electrocatalysis. With GC-QM the transition state geometry is allowed to change adiabatically as the applied potential is changed. Thus, we can predict which applied potential gives the optimum production of the desired products. GC-QM now enables theory to predict changes in transition state structure and free energy barrier as a function of potential directly from QM.

We have applied GC-QM to all four electrocatalytic processes listed above.

2. Validation of the accuracy of GC-QM for OER on Co/TiO2 single crystal nanoparticles (with Sen Zhang, U. Virginia)

The most important validation was on the Co/TiO2 single crystal nanoparticles prepared by Sen Zhang. We have predicted OER for many electrocatalysts but the validation with experiment has been difficult because the actual surface structure is almost never known from the experiment. However, Zhang prepared Co/TiO2 single crystal nanoparticles, for which the surface facets are all the same. The predicted free energies for all 9 steps of the OER on Co/TiO2 are shown in Figure 1 for applied potentials of 1.4 to 1.6 V. Figure 2 (right side) compares the predicted rate per surface site (TOF) with experiment, showing excellent agreement. The theory leads to currents about 25% larger than experiment, implying that the predicted transition state barrier is too low by only 0.03 eV! Figure 3 compares the current as a function of potential, making this new OER catalyst a substantial improvement over current generation OER catalysts.

3. validation for HER on WSe2 and WTe2 single layer electrocatalyst.

Chalcogenides such as WSe2 and WTe2 are layered making it possible to experimentally study the electrochemistry at the basal plane surface, so the surface structure is known for the theory. Figure 4 shows the GC-QM predicted current versus applied potential for the HER on WSe2 and WTe2, leading to onset potentials within ~ 0.05 V with experiment, a second very clean validation of GC-QM. Now we can use GC-QM to predict the performance numerous new potential electrocatalysts for OER, HER, N2RR, and ORR, enabling the experiments to focus only on the best predicted candidates.

4. HER rates on low index facets versus edges of Pt

Pt has long served as the gold standard for HER, but surprisingly there remains considerable uncertainty in the role played by step edges compared to the prominent facets. In collaboration with experimentalist Xiangfeng Duan at UCLA using ~1.5 nm diameter Pt nanowires (NW), we have made a major advance in showing that the edges lead to rates >100 times faster than the facets. This suggests that Pt catalysts might be made 10 or 100 times more active by optimizing edge concentrations.

Figures 5 and 6 summarize our results. In order to describe the water environment around the NW, we use 3061 water molecules, 60 H3O+, plus the Pt NW for over 10,000 atoms in a periodic box. This is far too large for QM (limited to <300 atoms and <100 ps for practical calculations), thus we used the ReaxFF reactive force field, trained to reproduce reaction trajectories from QM MD, but practical for systems with millions of atoms (cited >5300 times). Fig. 6c shows that the transition state free energies are substantially lower for edges. The result is that the edge rates (TOF) are > 100 faster than the facet rates (Fig. 6e), suggesting that rates measured on facets are probably dominated by the few percent edges present.

 


Last Modified: 07/03/2023
Modified by: William A Goddard
